text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on August 11 in history:
**1712 - In Switzerland the Treaty of Aargau was signed, ending the Swiss war and guaranteeing Protestant superiority over Catholic cantons.
1718 - English fleet under Admiral George Byng destroyed or captured 15 of 22 Spanish ships at the Battle of Cape Passaro off Sicily.
1858 - Christiaan Eijkman, Dutch physician, born. He won the Nobel prize for medicine for his discovery of Vitamin B in 1929.
**1877 - U.S. astronomer Asaph Hall discovered Deimos, (Panic in Greek) a satellite of Mars, at the Naval Observatory in Washington.

1919 - Scottish-born American industrialist Andrew Carnegie died at 83. His business grew into one of the largest iron and steel works in the United States and enabled him to make huge bequests, including public libraries in the U.S. and Britain.

**1945 - The World War Two Allies replied to a Japanese communique stating that the authority of the Emperor and the Japanese government to rule Japan would be subject to the Allied Supreme Commander.
1952 - King Hussein of Jordan succeeded to the throne after his father, King Talal, was deposed because of mental illness.
1956 - U.S. painter Jackson Pollock, leader of the Abstract Expressionist movement, died in a car accident. He introduced the technique of pouring paint on to canvass.
**1966 - A treaty to end three years of hostilities between Malaysia and Indonesia was signed in Jakarta.
1969 - Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda nationalised copper mining, key to Zambia's economy contributing over 50 percent of government revenue.
1990 - West German Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher's Free Democrats (FDP) merged with their liberal East German allies to become the first revived pan-German political party.
1994 - The Russian Supreme Court acquitted General Valentin Varennikov of high treason for joining those trying to overthrow Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in August 1991.

**1996 - Rafael Kubelik, Czech conductor, died aged 82. He made his debut with the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra in 1934, went into exile when the communists took power in 1948 and returned to conduct the opening concert of the 1990 Prague Spring music festival.
